questions.question: ASL sentence structure typically follows:
questions.explanation: ASL typically uses Time-Topic-Comment structure, where time comes first, then the topic, then the comment.

questions.question: The sign MOTHER involves:
questions.explanation: MOTHER is signed by placing an open hand with thumb on chin and tapping twice.

questions.question: To sign 'I eat breakfast every morning' in ASL, you would sign:
questions.explanation: ASL uses Time-Topic-Comment structure, so time (EVERY MORNING) comes first, then topic (BREAKFAST), then comment (I EAT).

questions.question: The sign LIKE involves:
questions.explanation: LIKE is signed with a flat hand, palm on chest, moving forward away from the body.

questions.question: To sign BROTHER, you:
options: Tap chin, then tap other hand
Tap forehead, then tap other hand
questions.explanation: BROTHER combines the DAD sign (tap forehead) with tapping the other hand's index finger.

questions.question: The sign UNDERSTAND involves:
options: Hand touching forehead, then moving forward
questions.explanation: UNDERSTAND is signed by touching the index finger to the forehead, then moving it forward.

questions.question: Give an example of ASL sentence structure using Time-Topic-Comment:
questions.explanation: ASL sentences typically start with time, then topic, then comment. Example: 'EVERY MORNING BREAKFAST I EAT' or 'YESTERDAY PIZZA I EAT'.

questions.question: How do you sign 'I like pizza' in ASL? (Show the word order)
questions.explanation: Both 'PIZZA I LIKE' (Topic-Comment) and 'I LIKE PIZZA' are acceptable in ASL, though Topic-Comment is more common.
